newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Durban harbour has 50 percent absenteeism.
newsitem.headline: Durban harbour has 50 percent absenteeism.

text.p: Durban's port was hit by 50 percent absenteeism on Monday morning as a one-day strike to protest against new labour legislation took hold, port officials said.

"We have provisional figures of 50 percent absenteeism this morning, but it is hard to say if it is on account of the strike or because of transport problems," spokeswoman Yvonne de Kock told Reuters.
Container handling services were 30 percent operational and figures were not immediately available for bulk and break-bulk terminals of Africa's busiest harbour, she said.
Port Elizabeth harbour had a 35 percent stayaway but services were not badly affected, a spokeswoman said.
"We have not been disrupted too badly because we made alternative working arrangements and also Mondays are not usually very busy," said Hanlie Botha.
Officials from Richards Bay harbour could not immediately be reached for comment.
A Durban Metro Rail official said commuter services had not been affected, but trains from the major townships serving the city were running at 40 to 50 percent of capacity.
